text: does anyone know off the top of their head a julia project that calls Rust in a substantial way?  Im looking for examples of julia interacting with some persistent resource (e.g. a socket) via Rust, rather than just calling some pure function

text: I was going through some intro rust stuff and Im thinking "how the hell can you build basic data structures with this" and then I look at the code for a linked list and its just unsafe blocks to do everything.  Haha.

elements.text: I was going through some intro rust stuff and Im thinking "how the hell can you build basic data structures with this" and then I look at the code for a linked list and its just unsafe blocks to do everything.  Haha.

text: That being said - making data structures in most systems languages in not fun. The nice thing is, there's lots of Crates of brave people who did a lot of them already :slightly_smiling_face:

text: `unsafe` is really just making a guarantee to the compiler that you know more than it does

text: code review is made a lot more simple when the potentially problematic sections are grouped in a similar scope, rather than needing to interpret and track them down

text: It is a little tricky. I've been working on a mini graph datastructure API in Rust. Haven't even gotten to performance yet.

text: Rust only guarantees that it produces safe binaries, it does not promise that all data structures can be implemented in a safe manner, trading safety for overhead is at the discretion of the user, something like `strlen` for example is forced to read each byte for safety

elements.text: Rust only guarantees that it produces safe binaries, it does not promise that all data structures can be implemented in a safe manner, trading safety for overhead is at the discretion of the user, something like
strlen
for example is forced to read each byte for safety
